feed.title: Pop Forecast
feed.subtitle: On our pop culture radar: Wanderlust, Goon, the Oscars, Sleigh Bells and more.

link.Abstract: Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd in Wanderlust.
link.title: Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd in Wanderlust

link.Abstract: Veterans Clooney, Pitt, Streep up against newcomers Mara, Davis, Dujardin.
link.title: Who Will Take Oscar home?

link.Abstract: We track down celebs to find out what they do when they're not on set or walking the red carpet.
link.title: Star Stalker

content.div:
"You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows," but these days, a guide through the seemingly endless flurry of pop culture is just what we need. With that in mind, here is what's on the radar screen in TV, music and film for the coming week.

• Movies

Big release: Goon (Feb. 24)

Big picture: It's like Adam Sandler's Happy Gilmore on skates. Seann William Scott (remember that annoying Stiffler guy from American Pie?) plays a dim-witted brute conscripted to play Canadian minor league hockey solely for his mighty fists (after all, he can barely stand on skates). According to the sports comedy: "He's not the Great One, he's not the Next One. He's . . . the Other One." I can only assume Don Cherry was the ghost writer on this script.

Forecast: Based on the book Goon: The True Story of an Unlikely Journey into Minor League Hockey, the movie has Canadiana written all over it - though I don't think NHL Commissioner Gary Bettman wants this kind of promotion for the game's dark arts. Eugene Levy provides some added levity as our lovable goon's father. Montreal actor Jay Baruchel co-stars as the titular characters lanky sidekick, and also co-wrote the script. Perhaps the team's coach sums things up best: "I want to see every one of you work your asses off until you puke your guts out. This is not f---ing baseball!"

Honourable Mention: Wanderlust. Jennifer Aniston goes topless (YOUR move Angelina Jolie) in this comedy produced by Judd Apatow. The film centres on Aniston and Paul Rudd as two high-flying city slickers who move to a remote, rural commune. Swedish-Canadian actress Malin Akerman (Watchmen) and the venerable, always reliable Alan Alda co-star. As do recreational drugs, free love and a lot of hippy-driven humour.

• TV

Big event: Oscars (Feb. 26, 8 ET/PT, CTV and ABC)

Big picture: Climb aboard your time machine and head to this year's Academy Awards! For starters, perpetual '90s host Billy Crystal (the anti-Ricky Gervais) returns to active duty at age 63. You can also watch a silent film - The Artist - take home best picture, and Martin Scorsese's Hugo - itself an ode to silent filmmaking - rack up other awards. Before long, Charlie Chaplin's ghost will likely be dancing across the stage with The Artist's beautiful ingenue, Berenice Bejo. And in the spirit of yesteryear, Charlie Sheen and Emilio Estevez can even pretend they're movie stars again!

Forecast: Crystal will bring a touch of old-school class to a nostalgic night. But I still wish the campaign to see The Muppets host the show had been successful. Perennial bachelor George Clooney may have finally found Mrs. Right in the pink, felt-laden form of Miss Piggy (Rest easy Kermit, "being green" could have become a lot harder).

Honourable mentions: Mighty Planes (Feb. 26, Discovery Channel, 8 ET/PT); Being Human - U.K. version (Feb. 25, SPACE, 9 ET/PT. Lovers of adventure and aviation will enjoy the new miniseries series, Mighty Planes, which launches with back-to-back episodes featuring modern planes on daring, hazardous missions. Lovers of vampires and werewolves will enjoy the launch of the fourth season of the British version of Being Human. Lovers of both will hope that somewhere out there a Hollywood hack is developing a script about vampire fighter pilots. Top Fangs, anyone? (I really need to quite my day job and move to L.A. My talents are being wasted.).

• Music

Big release on Feb. 21: Sleigh Bells (Reign of Terror)

Big picture: What would it sound like if a head cheerleader fronted a quirky heavy-metal band? The answer: Sleigh Bells. The Brooklyn duo return with an all-new album, Reign of Terror, based on the hypothetical U.S. presidency of Rick Santorum (nothing could be more horrifying than four years of those damn sweater vests). I'm kidding, of course. But this talented group are almost always cause to shake, rattle and roll. Reign of Terror offers a unique brew of bubble gum pop, hammering drums, '80s keyboard and blistering guitar.

Forecast: Sleigh Bells ring, are you listening? If not, you should be.

Honourable mention: Joel Plaskett Emergency (Scrappy Happiness). The talented Canadian singer-songwriter is currently conducting a unique online, musical experiment. His goal? Ten songs in 10 weeks. Plaskett is in the midst of recording and releasing one song a week - along with a "making of" video for every track - in order to create his new album. The tracks all debut on CBC Radio Two and Radio 3 on Mondays, and are then available on iTunes on Tuesdays. Track six will be released next week. For more details, go to www.joelplaskett.com and cbc.ca/joelplaskett.

clackner@postmedia.com
